Description: Fragment of rim and upper body of large Aeolian Grey Ware pottery open vessel, possibly a deep bowl or krater; carinated shoulder and everted rim with slight, flattened top; light grey fabric with large quantity of limestone and some mica inclusions; very worn dark grey slip; incised decoration consisting of two pairs of double wavy lines in shoulder zone, which also has some shallow grooving.
Curator's comments: Two drill holes in break from clay samples taken for Neutron Activation Analysis (NAA). By H. Mommsen (Bonn): sample Nauk 65 Group B- Troy (Troad) (See Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006, p. 58, fig. 13). From the same vessel as 1965,0930.506-7. Incised wavy lines are reminiscent of similar patterns found on grey wares from Troy, see Blegen, ‘Troy: Excavations conducted by the University of Cincinnati 1932-38’, Vol. IV (1958), and from Lesbos, see Lamb, ‘Grey Wares from Lesbos’, JHS 52 (1932) 1-12.
The shape is otherwise unattested at Naukratis, though has near parallels in sherds from Tell Dafana in the set British Museum 1888,0208.139.
Bibliographic references: Schlotzhauer & Villing 2006 / East Greek Pottery from Naukratis: The Current State of Research (p. 58, fig. 13, Table 1)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GL.173)
